Dialogue.NPCText:
Before you stands a fierce woman cloaked in furs and leaves, her face marked with streaks of green ash. She grips a flame-tipped spear, appraising you with wary, ember-bright eyes.

"Outsider, you tread close to the heart of Verdant lands. Speak plainly. Are you here to prove your worth—or to test my patience?"

Option.text: I seek to earn the respect of the Verdant Tribes.
I wish to join your warband.
What is the Green Flame?
Tell me about Hinokami.
Who were you before the Green Flame?
I am just passing through.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Tahlia narrows her gaze.

"Respect is not given, it is taken—earned in the wild, not the firepit. The jungle holds a beast our best have yet to bring down: the Dire Ashpaw. Track it. Slay it. Return with a trophy, and I will speak your name with honor."

Option.text: Where can I find the Dire Ashpaw?
I will face this beast for your respect.
That sounds too dangerous for me.
Is there another way to earn your trust?

Dialogue.NPCText:
Tahlia laughs, sharp and wild.

"The warband is no place for the soft-handed. Survive our trials, and perhaps I'll let you watch our backs. Fail, and the forest will reclaim your bones."

Option.text: What are your trials?
I am ready. Test me.
On second thought, I'll pass.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Tahlia taps her mask.

"The Green Flame is our fury—fierce, wild, and unbroken. It burns in those who fight for the tribe, not for self. Only the worthy bear its mark. Outsiders rarely understand... and even fewer survive to."

Option.text: How do I earn that mark?
I see. Thank you for the wisdom.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Tahlia scowls.

"Hinokami's people walk with order in their veins—every step rehearsed, every blade polished. They are worthy rivals, but their ways do not suit our wild. Still, when Minax’s darkness creeps, sometimes even old enemies must share the hunt."

Option.text: Are you at war with Hinokami?
Have you ever fought beside them?
Thank you for sharing your thoughts.

Dialogue.NPCText: "War? Not as the city-folk know it. We battle for pride, for territory, for the spirits of the land. When blood is spilled, it is to honor—not hatred. Still, I will not let their roots choke ours."

Option.text: Can I help ease tensions between tribes?
Sounds like you respect them, in a way.
Enough politics. Tell me of your warband.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Tahlia grins, exposing sharpened teeth.

"You want to walk with hunters? Prove your speed, your cunning, and your aim. Complete the warband’s gauntlet—three challenges: the Ember Path, the Blind Hunt, and the Ashen Leap. Return unbroken, and you may earn a place. Will you attempt it?"

Option.text: I accept the warband trials.
What are the details of each trial?
Maybe another time.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Tahlia hands you a carved bone token, etched with green flame.

"Take this. Survive our trials—bring me proof. Many enter, few return. Show me I am wrong to mistrust you."

Option.text: I will return victorious.
Any advice before I go?

Dialogue.NPCText: "Let the forest guide your steps. Listen before you strike, and trust nothing in the mist. The land remembers every footstep."

Option.text: Thank you, Tahlia.

Dialogue.NPCText: "Ember Path—outrun the burning thorns. Blind Hunt—track your prey with no eyes but your spirit. Ashen Leap—cross the chasm by faith and foot. Fail, and you feed the jungle. Succeed, and you may wear the warpaint."

Option.text: I am ready. Give me the trials.
On second thought, not today.

Dialogue.NPCText: "Seek the Ashpaw where the old trees burn brightest and the ground stinks of ash. Bring me its fang or pelt—not just its head. The spirits crave proof, not boasts."

Option.text: Understood. I will hunt the Ashpaw.
Another time, perhaps.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Tahlia offers a rare, approving nod.

"May the Green Flame light your path. Return with the proof—and see if the wild accepts you as one of its own."

Option.text: I will not disappoint you.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Tahlia’s eyes narrow.

"Words heal less than deeds, outsider. If you wish to play mediator, prove you walk in both worlds—help a Verdant child and a Hinokami elder. Then we’ll speak of peace."

Option.text: What tasks do you suggest?
Maybe I should leave politics alone.

Dialogue.NPCText: "Seek Eru, our Spirit Dancer, for the child in need. For Hinokami, the Lantern Keeper Kaoru may have work for you. Aid both—then return, and I will judge your worth."

Option.text: I will help both sides.
I will not get involved.

Dialogue.NPCText: "Respect, yes. But respect is not friendship. Even rival roots drink from the same river—yet fight for the sun."

Option.text: A wise way to see it.
Let’s change topic.

Dialogue.NPCText: "Once, when Minax's beasts threatened both our camps. Side by side, we drove them out, and shared meat after. But do not mistake a single night for a season."

Option.text: Thank you for your honesty.
How can I help the tribes against Minax?

Dialogue.NPCText: "Hunt Minax’s spies. Burn their totems. Free those tainted by her shadows. Our shamans—speak to Nura—know more. If you have the fire, strike at her heart."

Option.text: I will aid the shamans against Minax.
I need more time.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Tahlia steps aside, but never takes her eyes off you.

"Then move on. The wild judges all trespassers."

Option.text: Perhaps we will meet again.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Tahlia tilts her head, narrowing her eyes.

"Few ask that. Fewer deserve the answer. But... the Green Flame judges by deeds, not titles."

She gestures to the ash-streaks on her face.

"Before this? I had no name. Just smoke. I was a ghost-child, raised by the forest after raiders burned my kin. The wild fed me, taught me to strike, to vanish, to burn back."

"What do you truly want to know, outsider?"

Option.text: Why do you mistrust outsiders?
What do you fight for now?
Were you ever close to someone?
That explains much. I’ll leave you be.

Dialogue.NPCText:
"Because I've seen how 'civilized' folk repay kindness—with chains, steel, or fire. The last man I trusted tried to sell my tribe’s location to Hinokami for gold."

She clenches her jaw.

"Only the forest is honest. It kills when it must, nurtures when it wills. That, I respect."

Option.text: I understand your caution.
I hope you’ll come to trust me.
Maybe you’re too rigid.

Dialogue.NPCText:
"I fight to protect the grove, the children, the whispers of the old trees. I fight so our tribe doesn't vanish like mist in the sun."

"And perhaps... to prove that fire can heal as well as destroy."

Option.text: A noble reason. I respect that.
The forest is lucky to have you.
Sounds like you carry a burden.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Tahlia’s tone grows quiet.

"There was one... Kaelen. A hunter like me. He believed in unity, even with Hinokami. Took his case to the council."

She looks away.

"Minax’s cult found him first. Left only his mask in the river reeds."

"Since then, I’ve led. Alone. As fire does."

Option.text: I'm sorry. That pain... it shows your strength.
Did you ever find those responsible?
I should go.

Dialogue.NPCText:
"Not yet. But I will. There are whispers of a cult blade—a curved dagger, green flame etched in obsidian. If I ever see it again..."

She pauses.

"If you find it first, bring it to me. And I will owe you more than words."

Option.text: I'll keep watch for such a blade.
I hope you find peace, not just vengeance.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Tahlia studies you.

"Your heart is not yet blackened. Perhaps... you might earn trust in time." "You speak sweet, but the spirits say otherwise. I do not trust shadows."

Option.text: Then I will prove myself.
I’ll let my actions speak louder.
I’m no saint. But I’m honest.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Tahlia offers a rare nod of approval.

"Perhaps the wild hasn’t judged you harshly yet. That alone is rare."

"You’ve earned a sliver of my respect. Don’t waste it."

Option.text: Thank you, Tahlia.

Dialogue.NPCText:
You feel your body surge with a burst of primal energy.

(+2 Strength for 10 minutes)

Option.text: The Green Flame burns within me.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Tahlia’s eyes flash dangerously.

"Speak like that again, and the only roots you'll know are the ones covering your grave."

She turns away, dismissing you with disdain.

Option.text: Perhaps I’ve said enough.
Let’s talk of something else.
